titleStmt.title: An entry from the Journals of Hensley Henson

sourceDesc.bibl: Edited from the manuscripts in the custody of Durham Cathedral Library.

body.p: I wrote a number of letters including one to Brooks answering various questions which he had addressed to me, & suggesting that he might best fulfil his purpose of dealing with the subject of Christianity & Social Problems by giving a series of biographical addresses on famous Social Reformers who were also eminent Christians such as Elizabeth Fry, John Howard, William Wilberforce, Frederick Denison Maurice, Charles Kingsley & such like. Then after an early lunch I motored to Darlington, and took train for Rotherham. Leaving the first at 1.56p.m. I reached the last at a few minutes after 4p.m. There Lord Scarborough's car met me, & I was carried to Sandbeck about 6 or 7 miles in distance. After tea we went on the lake, & strolled in the gardens until it was time to dress for dinner.

Mine host and hostess spoke with some vigour of the inefficiency of a local parson. He was, they said, idle & useless. His wife was insane & would appear to have communicated some share of her infirmity to her partner, for his house was rendered almost inaccessible to the people by various protective devices. Nobody attended the services which were read in an empty church! And the Bishop?
